```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
set.seed(1)
```


Let's see what this does


```{r}
sim_mean_sd = function(n, mu = 2, sigma = 3) {
  
  sim_data = tibble(
    x = rnorm(n, mean = mu, sd = sigma),
  )
  
  sim_data |> 
    summarize(
      mu_hat = mean(x),
      sigma_hat = sd(x)
    )
}
```

Let's iterate to see how this works UNDER REPEATED SAMPLING!!

```{r}
output = vector("list", 100)

for (i in 1:100) {
  output[[i]] = sim_mean_sd(30)
}

sim_results = bind_rows(output)
```

```{r}
sim_results_df = 
  expand_grid(
    sample_size = 30,
    iter = 1:100
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    estimate_df = map(sample_size, sim_mean_sd)
  ) |> 
  unnest(estimate_df)
```

```{r}
sim_results_df |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = mu_hat)) + 
  geom_density()

sim_results_df |> 
  pivot_longer(
    mu_hat:sigma_hat,
    names_to = "parameter", 
    values_to = "estimate") |> 
  group_by(parameter) |> 
  summarize(
    emp_mean = mean(estimate),
    emp_sd = sd(estimate)) |> 
  knitr::kable(digits = 3)
```

use a map function

```{r}
sim_results_df =   
  map(1:100, \(i) sim_mean_sd(30, 2, 3)) |> 
  bind_rows()
```

```{r}
sim_results_df = 
  expand_grid(
    sample_size = c(30, 60, 120, 240),
    iter = 1:1000
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    estimate_df = map(sample_size, sim_mean_sd)
  ) |> 
  unnest(estimate_df)
```

```{r}
sim_results_df |> 
  mutate(
    sample_size = str_c("n = ", sample_size),
    sample_size = fct_inorder(sample_size)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = sample_size, y = mu_hat, fill = sample_size)) + 
  geom_violin()
```
